item.title: Introducing rBuilder 2.0.0
item.description:
rBuilder Online has been updated to version 2.0.0! Here's a summary of the most recent changes:
New Release Architecture
Redesigned the releases system, and replaced it with releases and builds, described below. Releases can now consist of an arbitrary set of builds; a build is a combination of group-trove (trove, version, flavor) + build type (ISO, VMware, QEMU, etc.). Project developers are now able to create and delete builds (e.g. for testing purposes). The creatiion, publishing and deleting of releases is still the exclusive domain of the project owner(s). Added release unpublish capability; unpublishing a release hides the release from the public, and allows you to edit the release contents. Releases may now be deleted after being published. The New Build page has been enhanced with an improved group trove selection mechanism, making it easier to choose the particular flavor of a group.
More information on the New Release Architecture here.
rMake
rBuilder can manage an rMake server local to the web browser’s machine. rMake integration with rBuilder is automatically enabled when you install rMake. Manipulating the rMake panel works similarly to Group Builder. rMake integration offers real-time status updates in the rMake panel, so you can monitor the status of your build from anywhere on the site. You can save and edit as many rMake builds as you desire.
More information on rMake is available here.
Other New Features
Searching (all types) now prioritizes exact matches above all other results. The file prefix may now be changed for ISOs, etc. You are no longer tied to using the source group-trove name. Demo (aka “Live”) CD/DVDs may now be created for x86 architectures. VMware images now default to bridged networking mode. rBuilder Online now produces VMware images with hardware version 4.
Bugfixes
VMware images generated with rBuilder Online no longer trigger an obscure VMware bug. (RBL-738) Opening two “create release” (now called “Create build”) pages at once no longer gives “requested item not found” (RBL-408).

item.title: rBuilder Online Updated
item.description:
rBuilder Online has been updated to version 1.6.3. New features include:
Added tar archive as a new release target; various ISO image sizes can now be selected as well. A bug causing VMware builds to fail occasionally has been fixed. The download landing page has been removed. The "show media check" option for installable ISOs now behaves correctly. The sense used to be backwards: selecting "show media check" would skip the media check, and vice-versa. Component removal from Group Builder now exists. For now, the settings are in the 'Edit Group' dialog, but this location may change in the future. Client cookie settings are tested at login instead of silently failing. Several months ago the default URL to rBuilder Online changed to /rbuilder/ from /. All RSS feeds and other links will not respond to the old URLs anymore.
Thanks for your interest in rBuilder Online!
item.content:encoded:
rBuilder Online has been updated to version 1.6.3. New features include:

  • Added tar archive as a new release target; various ISO image sizes can now be selected as well.
  • A bug causing VMware builds to fail occasionally has been fixed.
  • The download landing page has been removed.
  • The "show media check" option for installable ISOs now behaves correctly. The sense used to be backwards: selecting "show media check" would skip the media check, and vice-versa.
  • Component removal from Group Builder now exists. For now, the settings are in the 'Edit Group' dialog, but this location may change in the future.
  • Client cookie settings are tested at login instead of silently failing.
  • Several months ago the default URL to rBuilder Online changed to /rbuilder/ from /. All RSS feeds and other links will not respond to the old URLs anymore.

Thanks for your interest in rBuilder Online!

item.title: rPath is Hiring!
item.description:
rPath, Inc. is seeking people to join our team at our Raleigh, NC location. We're going to change the face of computing; for that we need your help. If any of the following positions look interesting, send your resume to jobs@rpath.com for a chance to work with some of the best and brightest the Linux community has to offer.
Build System
We're looking for a Software Engineer to work on rPath's core technologies. We're not looking for someone that just uses Linux distributions, we're looking for someone that creates them -- from bootstrap, to stabilization, to maintenance.
In other words, you have:
An understanding of Linux-based operating system structure and development including a deep understanding of the GNU toolchain (binutils, gcc, autoconf, automake, and friends)
Experience handling complex interdependencies between software components, both at build time and run time
An understanding of Software Configuration Management (SCM) concepts and techniques
Experience designing and developing web-based applications
Experience applying automated testing methodologies
Experience applying Object Oriented Programming principles to solve real-world problems
Did we just describe you? If so, let's talk -- email your resume to jobs@rpath.com!
Distribution
We're looking for a Software Engineer to help us develop our reference Linux distribution -- rPath Linux.
This means you have:
Experience developing Open Source software, especially participating in teams developing Open Source software and providing patches to other existing Open Source project teams
GNU toolchain and OS build process experience, including bootstrapping
Experience creating and building any type of Linux distribution
Is this you? If so, send your resume to jobs@rpath.com!
rBuilder
We're looking for a Software Engineer to help us develop rBuilder and associated technologies.
This means you have:
Experience designing, developing, and deploying large-scale Web applications
Knowledge of SQL
Familiarity with relational database design/administration using open source RDBMS technology
Experience configuring/tuning Apache for maximum performance in a high-traffic environment
Experience performance tuning open source relational databases
Recent Linux/Unix experience
Current object-oriented programming experience, with exposure to Python a plus
Sound familiar? If so, your resume needs to go to jobs@rpath.com!
Web Apps (Intern)
We're looking for a summer intern to help out with web application development. You'll be building the next generation of applications for managing virtual appliances built with rPath's core technologies. This is not your typical intern position!
Want to really have something to write about for that "What I did on my Summer vacation" essay? Email a resume to jobs@rpath.com!
Documentation
We're looking for a Technical Writer to help us describe all the cool stuff we're doing here at rPath.
We need people with 2+ years of real-world experience describing complex technical concepts to audiences of varying experience levels. In other words, if you find yourself delving into the latest technology and then explaining it to your friends for the fun of it, we should talk!
You must have solid Linux experience and a tool-agnostic approach to content delivery. If you know some Python and have experience with Linux package management technologies, so much the better.
Are you this person? If so, fire off a carefully-crafted resume to jobs@rpath.com!
